node.title: Government widens vaccine injury compensation scheme to win peace with renegade Senator
node.alt: Gerard Rennick sits on the backbench in the Senate looking into the distance
node.description: The government lowers the threshold for people to claim compensation for injury from the COVID-19 vaccine, in return for a small concession from a renegade Liberal senator who is vowing to vote against them.
node.content: ["Rogue Liberal backbencher Gerard Rennick has cut a deal over COVID-19 vaccines\u00a0but is still refusing to fully cooperate with the federal government.\u00a0", "The Queensland senator is against state governments and businesses mandating vaccines, and has\u00a0also raised concerns about the COVID-19 vaccine injury claims scheme.", "Currently, the government scheme covers injuries costing $5,000 and above due to the administration or an adverse event from a TGA-approved COVID vaccine.", "Senator Rennick met with Prime Minister Scott Morrison for a lengthy meeting earlier this week and with Treasurer Josh Frydenberg yesterday.\u00a0", "Following those discussions, the government will change how the vaccine claims scheme works so that the compensation threshold will be reduced from $5,000 to $1,000.\u00a0", "An online portal is expected to be launched next month for people to claim monetary support.\u00a0", "Under the current scheme, people claiming between $5,000 and $20,000 need to have been hospitalised for at least a night.\u00a0", "They must also provide evidence of what they need the money for, such as medical costs, lost wages and hospitalisation.\u00a0", "The government is yet to outline when the change in the compensation scheme comes into place.\u00a0", "In a statement, Health Minister Greg Hunt insisted the decision was not the result of any one person.", "\"The government has been considering this policy change for a number of weeks now and I thank all colleagues and stakeholders who have contributed to this decision,\"\u00a0he said.", "In return for the changes to the scheme,\u00a0Senator Rennick will support procedural votes, but he is still holding out on backing other government bills.\u00a0", "It means the government could still be required to rely on the crossbench for certain votes, because both Senator Rennick and his senate colleague\u00a0Alex Antic remain adamant they will not support government legislation until state vaccine mandates for some workers are eradicated.", "Mr Morrison has repeatedly insisted that the Coalition is a broad church of political views, however the small but noisy group of senators raising concerns about the mandates\u00a0is proving unhelpful for the Prime Minister in the final sitting fortnight.\u00a0", "Senior government Ministers have publicly called on the backbenchers to think carefully about how they vote in parliament and\u00a0reminded MPs their role is to keep Australians safe during the pandemic.", "Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese said it was an embarrassing position for the Prime Minister to be in.\u00a0", "\"This week, they can't get anything through the Parliament \u2014 they're in a state of chaos,\" he said.\u00a0", "Nationals senator Matt Canavan, who is also vocally concerned about vaccine mandates, said the federal government has shown, through its religious discrimination bill, that it is prepared to overrule state laws in certain situations.", "\"If it's good enough for the Commonwealth to use its powers to override state powers on religious freedom, surely it's good enough to use our powers to protect people's jobs,\" he said.\u00a0", "\"And that's what I think we can and should do.\""]
